publicationStmt.p: Distributed by Digital Scholarship Services at Lafayette College

lg.l: The following Ballad was writ by two or three Men of Wit upon their lying at the Rose Inn at Ockingham where the Daughter of the House is remarkably pretty & whose name is
Says my Uncle, I pray you discover What has been the Cause of your Woes,
That you pine & you whine like a Lover?I've seen Molly Mog of the Rose.
Oh Nephew! your Greif is but Folly; In town you may have better prog,
Half a crown there will get you a MollyA Molly much better than Mog.
The School boy's delight is a play-day, The School master's joy is to flog;
A Fop's the delight of a Lady,But mine is in sweet Molly Mog.
Will a Wisp leads the Traveller a gadding Thr'o ditch & thr'o Quagmire & Bog,
No Light can e'er set me a paddingBut the Eyes of my Sweet Molly Mog.
For Guineas in other Mens Breeches Your Gamesters will palm & will cog,
But I envy them none of their Riches,So I palm my Sweet Molly mog.
The Hart, thats half wounded, is ranging It Leaps here & there like Frog,
But my heart can never be changing;Its so fix'd on my sweet Molly Mog.
I know that by Wits 'tis recited That Women at best are a Clog;
But I am not so easily frightedFrom loving my sweet Molly Mog
A Letter, when I am inditing Comes Cupid & gives me a jog.
And I fill all the paper with writingOf nothing but sweet Molly Mog.
If I woud not give up the three Graces, (I wish I were hanged like a Dog.)
And at Court all the Drawing Room Faces,For a Glance at my Sweet Molly Mog
For those faces want Nature & Spirit And seem as cut of a Log,
Iuno, Venus & Pallas's MeritUnite in my Sweet Molly Mog.
Were Virgil alive with his Phyllis And writing another Ec overglogue
Both his Phyllis & fair AmarillisHe'd give for my sweet Molly Mog.
When Molly comes up with the Liquor, Then Iealousy sets me agog,
To be sure she is a bit for the VicarAnd so I shall Lose Molly Mog.Y29-631L
